content.description: This climb goes up a dihedral, goes left at a roof, and has an interesting thin face section leading to a chain anchor.
content.protection: 5 or 6 bolts to a 2 chain anchor. Optional medium cam placement below the roof
content.location: The fully bolted route left of Kip to a Handstand.

content.description: Not sure what this is called.  There are chains at the top but this isn't listed in the 2003 version of Boise Climbs and wasn't on MP.  There are bushes growing in this crack and pigeons roosting in it.  But it is a fun route.  Holds are good.
content.protection: Decent places for small cams

content.description: Opportunities to place supplementary gear if desired. Well protected for only having three bolts. Crux comes at the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts to Metolius rap hangers.

content.description:
Follows mostly positive crimps and edges up a column face for several bolts until the rock turns to a blonde color and becomes pocketed. The crux pulls through some of these pockets with a couple slopers.

Enjoyable climbing the whole way. A great Black Cliffs 5.10!
content.protection: 6 bolts, chains
content.location: First bolted route right of 'Chicken Wings.' Another route, 'Saturn' (12c), shares the first bolt and veers right. Sweat Engine goes directly up the plumb line.

content.description: Dihedral to the left of Lucky Pierre. Easy moves in the dihedral lead to some weirdness on the way to the chains.
content.protection: Gear, mainly smaller pieces. Once out of the dihedral, clip the last bolt on Lucky Pierre and finish at chain anchor.
content.location: Dihedral on the left of the Lucky Pierre column.

content.description: Climb straight up the spaced bolts without stemming onto the detached pillar to the right. I know this is contrived, but doing so would bring down the grade (and the quality of the climbing) considerably. If you play along, you will be rewarded with some extremely technical and insecure corner climbing with many blind and not so positive handholds. A clip or two may be spicier if you are short.
content.protection: 5 bolts. The anchor has been fitted with durable lower-offs courtesy of the ASCA.
content.location: Find the double varnished open-book corners just right of Bad Ethics.

content.description: Thin crack leads to short steep face protected by one bolt at crux. Finish moves on face are fun!
content.protection: Thin gear through crack to one bolt at crux and finishes at Metolius rap hangers.

content.description: Standard straightforward black cliffs trad climbing for the first 2/3rds with a cool bulge with great holds at the top. If 5.8 trad is your jam, check it out. Chains are located inconveniently too far to the right, but are workable.
content.protection: Gear to finger size. Optional #2 placement. Nuts work well.
content.location: 15ft right of loaded gun

content.description: The Spear is capped by an excellent finger crack crux near the top, but you have to pay your dues to get there. Start up junky rock on either side of the detached column, making sure not to kill yourself or your belayer with a loose block. I suspect this column has shifted out from the wall since the Epeldi guidebook was written. Once on top of the column, place a high piece, take a few deep breaths and punch it to the chains.
content.protection: Gear. Crux pieces are micro to finger size.
content.location: Just right of the very hard looking sport climb, Rainbow Warrior. The route name is painted at the base.

content.description: Great sport route with 4 bolts to Met Rap anchors.  The real trick is getting yourself to stay left around the 3rd bolt, it's seductive to go right where it drops the grade to a 5.7.  On tr, going up the right has a lot of balancy high-stepping and helps one develop good technique.
content.protection: Great sport route with 4 bolts to Met Rap anchors. Lots of places for gear.

content.description: The crack with a small roof between 'More Than I Can Chew' and 'Memorial Buttress'. It's short but has some interesting moves and good pro.
content.protection: Cams and nuts  to .75 Camalot, use either neighboring route's chains.

content.description: This is the hand/fist crack just left of Heat Miser, and can share that anchor. Can be top roped, once the rope is up on Heat Miser. I'm quite petite, so it was good feet and a big chunk of arm, in the crack!
content.protection: Anchors shared with Heat Miser.
content.location: General location is at the upstream end of the Mid Cliffs, just before the dihedrals disintegrate into a jumble. The columns lean back noticeably, and are easy to spot. Just left of the sport route Heat Miser.

content.description:
This is a classic route that seems to have developed a serious reputation. In my opinion, the serious stories I have heard about it are not warranted--it is a well-protected route. Certainly worth checking out!

Relatively easy climbing (5.10 or so) for the first four bolts leads to a technical traverse at the fifth bolt. Traverse left on thunderclings to a deep slot around the base of the arete. From there, a stellar boulder problem climbs the arete, finishing with a big move to a good, sloping jug just above the anchor. Don't sell yourself short by trying to clip the anchor without doing the last move--it's a great finish! (Although it is a bit of a heart breaker!)

Apparently a direct variation exists that skips the left traverse, but I haven't tried it. I have heard it ups the grade a couple letters.
content.protection: 6 bolts to rap rings
content.location: The bolted line just left of The Spear. (The Spear's name is painted at its base).

content.description: Directly to the left of Kip to a Handstand. Straightforward face climbing for the first 3 bolts. Step across a gap to a solid stance to clip the 4th bolt. Excellent route for leaders looking to push past 5.10a.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chains

content.description: Easy moves lead to fun face climbing. Crux is at the top.  Fall Shade until 10am.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chains.
content.location: Just left of Ajax

content.description: This is a nice well protected trad climb that doesn't see much traffic. Unfortunately the climb starts out ledgy and vegetated, but once the real climbings begin, the quality is solid. Climb twin cracks to a hand crack and then a wide pod going out a bulge. Surmounting the bulge is the crux, and will likely lure you into a beached whale position.
content.protection: Gear to #3 Camalot.
content.location: Near the far right end of the Mid Cliffs.

content.description: A nice moderate trad line with good pro, this one starts on top of a column in a dihedral, then it follows a cool flake up to the anchors.
content.protection: Trad gear with 2 chain anchors.
content.location: This is the SECOND dihedral to the Left of 'Nut and a Sling'. I don't recommend the first dihedral to the left of Nut and a Sling, it's got some gnarly loose blocks in it.

content.description: The crack to the right of Memorial Buttress. Fairly straightforward crack with no distinct crux. Good pro.
content.protection: Cams and Nuts to #2 Camalot.  Chain anchors
content.location: Crack just to the right of Memorial Buttress

content.description: Start with standard Black Cliff's stemming between columns, which leads up to a short crux, with a final thoughtful move to the chains. There is some loose rock on the sides of this climb.
content.protection: Single set of cams from C3's to gold Camalot, nuts.
content.location: On the right side of the Mid Cliffs, right of In Vitro, but before the obvious thin crack of Nikita.

content.description: Nothing special, just another ok 5.8 trad climb at the cliffs. There's no gear for the first 15ft or so but it is all secure easy climbing. The rest of the route takes solid gear.
content.protection: Gear to #2 Camalot. Two chain anchors
content.location: Look for a giant white painted target on the wall with the number 9 on it. It's toward the far right side of the mid cliffs wall

content.description: Easier than it looks, thanks to holds which are hard to see from below, but the gear is fairly small the whole way. Crux comes at a bulge 2/3 of the way up where the feet disappear for a bit.
content.protection: Mostly small gear, from C3's to .5 Camalot, nuts.
content.location: Right side of the Mid Cliffs. Obvious clean, thin crack.

content.description: Good for first-timers on top rope.  Good first lead.  A few fun variations.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains
content.location: Around the "corner" from Lucky Pierre.

content.description: Crux is near the top.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains
content.location: Just right of Fat Ankles

content.description: Follow thin hands crack to a roof with a bolt on the lip.
content.protection: Gear to two bolts at the top. Shares an anchor with In Vivo.
content.location: About 2/3 of the way down the mid cliffs from the left. On the face of a small outcrop.

climbs.name: Lucky Pierre
climbs.fa: Dan Smith, G Smith, S Epeldi, J Laughlin

content.description: Start up the crack/corner right of the bolts, moving onto the pillar before the small roof. Fun climbing.
content.protection: 5 bolts + anchors.
content.location: Look for the bolted pillar to the right of Rectal Cranial Insertion, before the cliff band gets broken.

content.description: Climber's left side of the Mid Cliffs. Climb the hand sized crack right of Tidy Up, to shared anchors.  Starts on obvious belay platform.  See picture.
content.protection: Standard rack to chains

content.description:
This route is just right of Fat Ankles, and can be top roped from the anchors on that route. The bottom part includes a little vertical bushwhacking! Syringa, I believe, Idaho's state flower and quite pretty when blooming.

It is not great rock on the bottom half, pretty broken up, but that also means an abundance of easy hand and foot holds. Very easy climbing, perhaps even 5.4. The top half would go to the Fat Ankles anchors, and be a little more difficult.
content.protection: Use a top rope from Fat Ankles anchor
content.location: To the immediate right of Fat Ankles, with some bushes growing out of it.

content.description: Climb a cool dihedral with lots of holds and gear placement options.  Easy stemming leads to a crack surrounded by smooth walls where you will have to commit to jamming or liebacking (crux).  A few moves of that and then easy cruising to the chains.
content.protection: Gear to chains.
content.location: Climber's left side of the Mid Cliffs.  Just left of the platform built to belay Fat Ankles.  See pic.

content.description: The namesake lightning crack zigzag is the top quarter/third of the climb..Not sure if the bottom is the tight dihedral, or the face just right of the dihedral, but both are fun!
content.protection: Hand/fist sized (BD #2 & 3) for lower dihedral, finger (BD .5 or .75) sized for face at the top.Can be easily topped out, but be careful of loose rubble on top.
content.location: Look for the zig zag crack at the top. Just left of the 3 bolt climb Tidy Up.

content.description: Easy ground leads to a boulder problem pulling over the roof (not as hard as it looks).
content.protection: 3 bolts to chains

content.description: This route is listed in Boise Climbs. It is the crack to the left of Little Boots and shares chains with that route. The bottom half is easy. Crux is near the top.  The holds get thin but a leap of faith is rewarded with bomber holds.  From there pull yourself up onto the shelf and you have reached the chains.
content.protection: Good crack most of the way up.  Anchor chains at top (Little Boots anchor)
content.location: This route is just to the right of Little Boots and uses the same anchor.

content.description: Fun, steep moves lead to a good stance after the third bolt. From here, head up and right past the fourth clip, to a steep, featured arete.
content.protection: 5 bolts, optional tiny C3 for the runout between the third and fourth bolts.
content.location: On the right side of the Mid Cliffs, right of Nut 'n a Sling, left of Nikita.

content.description:
Great climb. Lower grade up until the crux where you pass over a roof. There is potential for a nasty fall if you biff the move over the bulge while leading, but there is additional protection part way up the bulge.

There is a small shelf to take a breather after making it over the roof and enjoy the view before reaching the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains

content.description: It called heat miser for a reason.  In late spring/early summer it heats up pretty fast on a sunny day.
content.protection: Bolts

content.description: This is a pretty cool route with great exposure at the crux. It goes up a scaly crack to a roof, then left at the roof. The moves to get out from under the roof are the crux. It takes great pro the whole route as long as you're careful about the flakiness in the lower crack.
content.protection: Gear including a #3 Camalot. Anchors recently replaced with beefy stainless + chains.
content.location: Maybe 50ft right of Sweat Engine?

content.description: Some smearing and stemming around the 3rd bolt make the crux.  It's a reach for the chains if you're not tall.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains

content.description: Climb up a nice, right-facing corner on tips and good edges (8 or 9-ish) until beneath a roof feature. The original line, 'Wooly Footed Vixen,' (10-) veers right here. Chicken Wings is actually a variation to this and heads directly over the roof passing one bolt. The headwall above the roof sports the crux on thin, bouldery climbing. A bit of a slap in the face after the lower bit. Fun movement on mostly clean rock.
content.protection:
Mostly small cams (#0-2 TCU's). Can get a good finger/ring-sized piece under the roof (use runner).

Save a draw for the bolt.
content.location: A few columns right of the thin crack 'Nikita.' Look for a right-facing corner capped by a slanting roof with a lone bolt and chains on top.

content.description: The usual Black Cliffs' "boulder problem in the sky." Enjoyable climbing overall, if somewhat short.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chain anchors. You can clip the crux bolt from under the roof. You should extend the clip under the roof with a sling so that when you lower the rope stays out of the crack in the roof.
content.location: About 50 feet to the left of Snake Eyes. Look for the obvious roof with bolts leading up to it.

content.description: Fun little climb that can be top roped after you lead Heat Miser on the right.  Good placement for gear on the lower half but gets very thin towards the top.
content.protection: Anchors on top.
content.location: This route is on the right of Heat Miser and shares the same anchor.

content.description: Start in the dihedral to the right of 'Nut n' a Sling', pass a small roof, and climb the hand crack until level with the anchors to your left, then traverse to them. Easy to find solid gear on this one.
content.protection: Gear to #2 Camalot
content.location: One dihedral to the right of Nut n a Sling. It's just a few feet left of an offwidth with a big roof, Bloody Crack.

content.description: A wide crack (BD 5-6) leading up to and through a roof.
content.protection: The back of the crack can be protected with thin hand sizes. A #5 will make the crux much more comfortable.
content.location: This wide crack can be easily seen when approached from the left. It’s on the left side of a small outcrop.

content.description: This is listed in Boise Climbs with a thumb down due to some loose rocks.  It seems pretty solid now.  However there is a loose flake about two thirds of the way up.  This route is just to the left of Fat Ankles.  It is possible to TR this by climbing Fat Ankles first.  Lots of good places for gear if you want to lead.
content.protection: Chains at the top
content.location: The chains just to the left of Fat Ankles

content.description: Climb easy basalt until you reach two bolts placed next to eachother (use the one on the right, the one on the left is loose) with a bulge above.
content.protection: About 6 bolts to chains and one cold shut
content.location: The route  is easy to find because the name is scratched into the rock at the base of the climb.

content.description: I'm mainly posting this route to advise people to avoid it, the climbing wasn't great, and it the anchor in the Epeldi book isn't there anymore! It starts in a chimney, climbs a finger crack and goes up and around a wide flaring roof. I used the chains to the right on Weenie Roast but it wasn't exactly ideal.
content.protection: Gear. NO ANCHORS!
content.location: Go about 30ft right of the Number Nine. Find a chimney perched up on some blocks. That's the start. Avoid it because there's no anchor!

content.description: Fun 5.8
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains
content.location: Just to the right of "More than I can chew"

content.description: The crux is near the top. It's a nice climb to a sweet crux.  Fall shade until 10am.
content.protection: Four bolts to chains.  You can take pro for additional comfort, or do it all trad.
content.location: Impossible to describe. Get Sandy Epeldi's "Boise Climbs" from the Boise REI or ask a local. (Epeldi put together an excellent guide book - arguably worth buying even if you're only in the area once.)

content.description: The rock is in good condition. It's a nice climb, for basalt. Not super memorable, but worth the trip.
content.protection: Guidebook says, "Pro is a bit sparse." You can toprope from the Ajax anchors.
content.location: Just right of Ajax
